page.title: Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Existential
page.introduction: Existential sentences are similar to copular sentences, except that they use a word or words meaning ‘there is’ or ‘there exists’ along with a nominal phrase and usually a location. English examples include:

EnglishExample.exItem: There is a book on the table.

page.introduction: Some languages instead have a separate existential verb, such as hay ‘there exists’ in Spanish. Other languages have a whole set of existential verbs which express the position of the object being described.

form.instruction: Add the feature exist to the appropriate verbs in the lexicon. Since the existential verbs are a small, closed set, the feature must be entered in the lexicon on the appropriate verbs; the default setting is -exist. Also add the feature exist to any copular verbs that may be used in these existential constructions.

Add the feature exist to the existential word in the lexicon. We assume that this word will have the category Adv. If it does not, please also add the feature makeAdv to change the category for these constructions. If the existential word is synonymous with another word or another category in your language, you will need to make two separate lexical entries.
